ci_support_linux_64_r_base4.4.yaml:
c_compiler:
- gcc
c_compiler_version:
- '14'
c_stdlib:
- sysroot
c_stdlib_version:
- '2.17'
channel_sources:
- conda-forge
channel_targets:
- conda-forge main
cran_mirror:
- https://cran.r-project.org
docker_image:
- quay.io/condaforge/linux-anvil-x86_64:alma9
pin_run_as_build:
  r-base:
    min_pin: x.x
    max_pin: x.x
r_base:
- '4.4'
target_platform:
- linux-64

about.description:
The leader clustering algorithm provides a means for clustering a set of data
points. Unlike many other clustering algorithms it does not require the user to
specify the number of clusters, but instead requires the approximate radius of a
cluster as its primary tuning parameter. The package provides a fast implementation
of this algorithm in n-dimensions using Lp-distances (with special cases for p=1,2,
and infinity) as well as for spatial data using the Haversine formula.

The leader clustering algorithm provides a means for clustering a set of data
points. Unlike many other clustering algorithms it does not require the user to
specify the number of clusters, but instead requires the approximate radius of a
cluster as its primary tuning parameter. The package provides a fast implementation
of this algorithm in n-dimensions using Lp-distances (with special cases for p=1,2,
and infinity) as well as for spatial data using the Haversine formula.

name: r-leadercluster

about.description:
The leader clustering algorithm provides a means for clustering a set of data
points. Unlike many other clustering algorithms it does not require the user to
specify the number of clusters, but instead requires the approximate radius of a
cluster as its primary tuning parameter. The package provides a fast implementation
of this algorithm in n-dimensions using Lp-distances (with special cases for p=1,2,
and infinity) as well as for spatial data using the Haversine formula.

raw_meta_yaml:
{% set version = '1.5' %}
{% set posix = 'm2-' if win else '' %}

package:
  name: r-leadercluster
  version: {{ version|replace("-", "_") }}

source:
  url:
    - {{ cran_mirror }}/src/contrib/leaderCluster_{{ version }}.tar.gz
    - {{ cran_mirror }}/src/contrib/Archive/leaderCluster/leaderCluster_{{ version }}.tar.gz
  sha256: ae2254e88e8ff17b8498155a024c656e17456dab2438e0b5a21ed070b23a95aa

build:
  number: 0
  rpaths:
    - lib/R/lib/
    - lib/
  missing_dso_whitelist:
    - '*/R.dll'        # [win]
    - '*/Rblas.dll'    # [win]
    - '*/Rlapack.dll'  # [win]

requirements:
  build:
    - {{ compiler('c') }}              # [not win]
    - {{ compiler('m2w64_c') }}        # [win]
    - {{ stdlib('c') }}                # [not win]
    - {{ posix }}filesystem        # [win]
    - {{ posix }}make
    - {{ posix }}sed               # [win]
    - {{ posix }}coreutils         # [win]
    - {{ posix }}zip               # [win]
    - cross-r-base {{ r_base }}    # [build_platform != target_platform]
  host:
    - r-base
  run:
    - r-base

test:
  commands:
    - $R -e "library('leaderCluster')"           # [not win]
    - "\"%R%\" -e \"library('leaderCluster')\""  # [win]

about:
  home: https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=leaderCluster
  license: LGPL-2.0-only
  summary: Leader Clustering Algorithm
  description: |
    The leader clustering algorithm provides a means for clustering a set of data
    points. Unlike many other clustering algorithms it does not require the user to
    specify the number of clusters, but instead requires the approximate radius of a
    cluster as its primary tuning parameter. The package provides a fast implementation 
    of this algorithm in n-dimensions using Lp-distances (with special cases for p=1,2, 
    and infinity) as well as for spatial data using the Haversine formula.
  license_family: LGPL
  license_file:
    - '{{ environ["PREFIX"] }}/lib/R/share/licenses/LGPL-2'

extra:
  recipe-maintainers:
    - conda-forge/r

about.description:
The leader clustering algorithm provides a means for clustering a set of data
points. Unlike many other clustering algorithms it does not require the user to
specify the number of clusters, but instead requires the approximate radius of a
cluster as its primary tuning parameter. The package provides a fast implementation
of this algorithm in n-dimensions using Lp-distances (with special cases for p=1,2,
and infinity) as well as for spatial data using the Haversine formula.
